name: NewYorker
text:
The Borowitz Report: Barack Obama recently passed a cognitive test that required him to recite the first fifty digits of pi, the former President has disclosed.
https://t.co/vAUWe33mSk

name: NewYorker
text: The movie “The Hate U Give” isn’t a bold or bracing work of stylistic originality; rather, it’s one in which a familiar manner is expanded and elevated by way of insight and sensibility. https://t.co/qTWyPFmNPk

name: NewYorker
text: Our real concern should be equality not in material benefits, Elizabeth Anderson argues, but in social relations: democratic equality. https://t.co/AcuL6J3VAs

name: NewYorker
text: Since the beginning of the pandemic, advocates for victims of domestic violence have been warning, with terrible accuracy, that the forced intimacy resulting from quarantine would lead to a surge in abuse. https://t.co/tJUVbPIEYI

name: NewYorker
text: The German pianist Igor Levit is used to playing carefully chosen programs at concert halls all over the world. At home, he can choose whatever pieces ﬁt his mood. https://t.co/kzSdZXJ4Jn

name: NewYorker
text: Josephine Decker’s new film "Shirley," starring Elisabeth Moss as Shirley Jackson, is an audacious director’s experiment in commercial filmmaking—and it's a successful one. https://t.co/jHiByI9O2C

name: NewYorker
text: “Although many are becoming comfortable spurting out phrases like ‘systemic racism,’ the solutions proposed remain mired in the system that is being critiqued,” @KeeangaYamahtta writes. https://t.co/i0082iNOlQ

name: NewYorker
text: A 24-year-old candidate named Madison Cawthorn, who won’t reach the eligibility age for Congress until his birthday, in August, crushed the Trump-endorsed candidate Lynda Bennett by a margin of nearly two to one. https://t.co/3JwRm5QX9L

name: NewYorker
text: Is Jon Stewart’s new comedy, "Irresistable," starring Steve Carell, a sendup of big-time political operatives or of small-town America? https://t.co/GQqF0xA7J9

name: NewYorker
text: Emma Cline on the reality created by fiction and her favorite odious men in literature. https://t.co/jBO4E0mGbk

name: NewYorker
text: Not unlike its protagonist, David Mitchell’s new novel, “Utopia Avenue,” turns out to have been a sort of host for something else entirely. https://t.co/Izuvf17Rw1

name: NewYorker
text: What the past three months of relative confinement—and the resulting shift from theatrical to online releases—have proved is that movie theatres, particularly the multiplexes, hardly matter now, @tnyfrontrow writes. https://t.co/HJdqX6wn2j

name: NewYorker
text:
"The past few months have been, you could say, no picnic," @hannahgoldfield writes. "Might I suggest . . . a picnic?"
https://t.co/xsARgtRijK

name: NewYorker
text:
The man who knew everything, who was born on this day in 1894, couldn’t see that his longed-for state of higher reality already existed.
https://t.co/wCcyr2gm9z

name: NewYorker
text: "If you're the child of an immigrant to Italy," @ngofeenm says, "you have to wait until you're 18 to apply for citizenship." Listen to a new episode of #NewYorkerRadio, which looks at the struggle of Black Italians to change Italy’s laws. https://t.co/02IpclWyDk

name: NewYorker
text: Next month marks the centenary of the ratiﬁcation of the 19th Amendment, which is sometimes described as having “given” women the right to vote. In fact, it was a hard-won victory on the part of suﬀragists who’d been agitating for more than 70 years. https://t.co/bQqK3Il3nS

name: NewYorker
text: RT @IChotiner: New Interview: I talked with Carrie Cordero about what federal agents are really doing in Portland, the shaky legal basis for Trump’s actions, and how the creation of D.H.S. gave the President vast new powers. https://t.co/nRfSODmFXb

name: NewYorker
text:
The weaknesses that have left our primary-care system so vulnerable to the coronavirus pandemic have been understood for decades, yet change has come at a glacial pace.
https://t.co/tTvVPSpRkL

name: NewYorker
text: Talking Heads’ drummer, Chris Frantz, on moving to the Lower East Side in the 1970s with the hope of starting a band. https://t.co/n3cM27gbVE

name: NewYorker
text: Jane Austen lived and wrote and died in a period that might have seemed to her almost as convulsive as ours does to us. https://t.co/uvUoleRBVI

name: NewYorker
text: “In the United States, we do not have a domestic-security service or an internal-security service,” @carriecordero said. “And we deliberately don’t have one because that’s the kind of thing that can turn into a Stasi-like organization.” https://t.co/1GyDarS8jc

name: NewYorker
text: Audra McDonald says she doesn’t love performing virtually but she understands the necessity of it, “because we still need the arts. We need theatre. We need music. We need inspiration. We need catharsis. We need being in touch with our humanity.” https://t.co/M14JaZ6SVl

name: NewYorker
text: .@samknightwrites on observing swifts while feeling trapped by the coronavirus: “They peeled off from the rest of the birds about 70 million years ago. They slept on the wing above dinosaurs. What is a pandemic to them?” https://t.co/hCEdf97pd9

name: NewYorker
text: In Portland, we are watching the perfect and perhaps inevitable combination of a domestic-security superagency and a President who rejects all mechanisms of accountability, @mashagessen writes. https://t.co/aJZnzzs870
